questions.text: Which among the following requires BSL-3?
questions.solution:
Choice C: XDR-TB (Extensively Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis)

  • Biosafety Level 3 (BSL-3) is required for handling highly infectious airborne pathogens that can cause severe disease but have available treatments.
  • XDR-TB (Extensively Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis) is a highly drug-resistant strain of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, resistant to isoniazid, rifampin, fluoroquinolones, and second-line injectable drugs.
  • Why BSL-3?
    • Airborne transmission (via respiratory droplets).
    • High risk of infection in laboratory settings.
    • Requires biosafety cabinets, controlled airflow, and personal protective equipment (PPE) to prevent exposure.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: CCF (Chronic Cryptococcal Fungemia)

  • Cryptococcus species (fungus) is handled under BSL-2, not BSL-3.
  • Transmission: Inhalation of spores, but not highly contagious.
  • Does not require advanced containment measures.

Choice B: Ebola

  • Requires BSL-4, not BSL-3.
  • Transmission: Direct contact with bodily fluids (not airborne).
  • BSL-4 containment includes full-body positive pressure suits, isolation rooms, and restricted access.

Choice D: Salmonella

  • Handled under BSL-2, unless it’s a highly virulent strain.
  • Transmission: Fecal-oral route (foodborne), not airborne.
  • Standard precautions (BSL-2) are sufficient for routine laboratory work.

Key Takeaway

XDR-TB requires BSL-3 containment due to its airborne transmission and high drug resistance, making it a serious laboratory hazard.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms require reverse transcriptase enzyme before amplification in PCR?
questions.solution:
Choice B: RSV (Respiratory Syncytial Virus)

  • RSV is an RNA virus, specifically a negative-sense single-stranded RNA virus.
  • Reverse transcriptase (RT) is required because:
    • PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) amplifies DNA, not RNA.
    • RNA viruses must be converted into complementary DNA (cDNA) before amplification.
    • Reverse Transcription PCR (RT-PCR) is used for RSV detection.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: CMV (Cytomegalovirus)

  • CMV is a DNA virus(Herpesviridae family).
  • No need for reverse transcriptase, as PCR can directly amplify DNA.

Choice C: Parvovirus B19

  • Parvovirus is a DNA virus(single-stranded DNA virus).
  • PCR can directly amplify DNA, no need for reverse transcription.

Choice D: HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus)

  • HSV is a DNA virus(Herpesviridae family).
  • PCR directly amplifies viral DNA, so reverse transcriptase is not needed.

Key Takeaway

RSV requires reverse transcriptase before PCR because it is an RNA virus, whereas DNA viruses (CMV, Parvo, HSV) do not.

questions.text: Which among the following is a superantigen?
questions.solution:
Choice A: Streptococcus pyogenic exotoxin (SPE)

  • Superantigens re toxins that cause excessive activation of T-cells by binding directly to MHC-II and T-cell receptors, leading to a massive cytokine release ("cytokine storm").
  • Streptococcus pyogenic exotoxins (SPE-A, SPE-B, SPE-C) are produced by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus) and cause:
    • Scarlet fever(SPE-A, SPE-C).
    • Streptococcal toxic shock syndrome (TSS)(SPE-A).
    • Necrotizing fasciitis(SPE-B).
  • Mechanism: Activates ~20% of T-cells, leading to massive cytokine release (IL-1, IL-2, TNF-α, IFN-γ), causing shock and multi-organ failure.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice B: Clostridium difficile exotoxin

  • difficileproduces Toxin A (enterotoxin) and Toxin B (cytotoxin).
  • These are NOT superantigens but act by:
    • Glucosylating Rho proteins, disrupting the cytoskeleton of intestinal epithelial cells, leading to diarrhea and pseudomembranous colitis.

Choice C: Corynebacterium diphtheriae diphtheria toxin

  • Diphtheria toxin is an AB toxin that inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylation of EF-2, leading to cell death.
  • Causes pharyngeal pseudomembranes, myocarditis, and neuropathy, but does not function as a superantigen.

Choice D: Pseudomonas exotoxin (Exotoxin A)

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosaproduces Exotoxin A, which also ADP-ribosylates EF-2, leading to cell death.
  • It acts similarly to diphtheria toxin but is not a superantigen.

Key Takeaway

The superantigen among the options is Streptococcus pyogenic exotoxin (SPE-A, SPE-C), which triggers massive immune activation and cytokine release, leading to toxic shock-like syndrome and necrotizing fasciitis.

questions.text: A patient manifested with fever and rashes and retro orbital headaches since 3 days. Investigations showed Hb = 14g/dl , WBC = 4000/ul, platelet = 89000/ul. All of the following can be done to confirm the diagnosis except?
questions.solution:
Choice D: IgM ELISA (Incorrect test for early diagnosis)

  • The patient presents with fever, rash, and retro-orbital headache, along with leukopenia and thrombocytopenia, which strongly suggests Dengue fever.
  • IgM ELISA (enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay) detects IgM antibodies, but:
    • IgM antibodies appear after 4-5 days of illness.
    • Since the patient is in early stages (day 3 of illness), IgM may still be negative, making it an unreliable test at this point.
    • Best used for late diagnosis (after day 5).

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: NS1 Antigen Test

  • NS1 (Non-Structural Protein 1) antigen is present in the blood from day 1-5 of infection.
  • Highly sensitive for early Dengue diagnosis.
  • Used for both primary and secondary infections.

Choice B: Virus Culture

  • Dengue virus can be isolated from blood in the first 4-5 days of illness.
  • Rarely done in clinical practice due to time consumption but is technically a confirmatory test.

Choice C: RT-PCR (Reverse Transcriptase Polymerase Chain Reaction)

  • Detects Dengue viral RNA in the first 5 days of infection.
  • Highly specific and sensitive for early diagnosis.
  • Used when NS1 antigen or clinical suspicion is high.

Key Takeaway

For early Dengue diagnosis (Day 3 of illness), NS1 antigen or RT-PCR should be used. IgM ELISA is not reliable at this stage Since IgM antibodies appear after 4-5 days.

questions.text: A PATIENT WITH HIGH GRADE FEVER, NECK STIFFNESS AND KERNIG'S SIGN WAS POSITIVE. CSF ANALYSIS SHOWED NEUTROPHILS, PROTEIN - 80 MG/DL, GLUCOSE - 20 MG/DL. WHAT IS YOUR DIAGNOSIS?
questions.solution:
Choice C: Bacterial Meningitis

  • The patient presents with high-grade fever, neck stiffness, and a positive Kernig's sign, which are classic signs of meningitis.
  • CSF findings indicate bacterial meningitis:
    • Neutrophilic predominance→ Suggests bacterial infection.
    • High protein (80 mg/dL)→ Indicates increased permeability due to inflammation.
    • Low glucose (20 mg/dL)→ Bacteria consume glucose, leading to hypoglycorrhachia (normal CSF glucose: 50-80 mg/dL).
  • Common causes: Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, Haemophilus influenzae (children), Listeria monocytogenes (elderly & immunocompromised).

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Tubercular Meningitis

  • Typically presents with subacute or chronic onset(weeks to months), not acute high fever.
  • CSF findings differ:
    • Lymphocytic predominance(not neutrophils).
    • Very high protein (>100-150 mg/dL).
    • Very low glucose (<10-20 mg/dL).
    • Thick basal exudates on imaging(MRI/CT).

Choice B: Viral Meningitis

  • Usually presents with mild symptoms compared to bacterial meningitis.
  • CSF findings:
    • Lymphocytic predominance(instead of neutrophils).
    • Normal or slightly elevated protein.
    • Normal glucose levels.
    • Common causes: Enteroviruses, HSV-2, Arboviruses.

Choice D: None of the Above

  • Incorrect because CSF findings are clearly suggestive of bacterial meningitis.

Key Takeaway

The presence of neutrophils, high protein, and low glucose in CSF confirms bacterial meningitis.

choices.text: Postpone antiretroviral therapy for 2 to 3 weeks
Initiate treatment with amphotericin B only
Brain imaging shows changes in 80% patients

questions.text: A HIV positive adult manifested with neck rigidity and papilledema. CSF sample showed capsulated organism positive for Indian ink staining. Which of the following statement is true?
questions.solution:
Choice D: Brain imaging shows changes in 80% of patients

  • The patient is HIV-positive with neck rigidity and papilledema, which suggests cryptococcal meningitis.
  • CSF shows a capsulated organism on India Ink stain, which confirms Cryptococcus neoformans(a common opportunistic fungal infection in AIDS patients).
  • Neuroimaging findings in 80% of cases include:
    • Dilated Virchow-Robin spaces(gelatinous pseudocysts).
    • Leptomeningeal enhancement.
    • Hydrocephalus or cerebral atrophy.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Postpone antiretroviral therapy (ART) for 2 to 3 weeks

  • Partially correct but not the best answer.
  • ART is usually delayed by 4-6 weeks n cryptococcal meningitis to prevent immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS).
  • The 2-3 weeks delay is typically applied in Tuberculous meningitis, not Cryptococcus.

Choice B: CSF pressure mostly remains normal

  • Raised intracranial pressure (ICP) is common.
  • Cryptococcal meningitis causes increased CSF viscosity, leading to obstructive hydrocephalus and very high CSF pressure (>250 mm H2O).
  • Repeated lumbar punctures are required to relieve ICP.

Choice C: Initiate treatment with Amphotericin B only

  • Combination therapy is required.
  • Standard treatment includes:
    • Amphotericin B + Flucytosine for 2 weeks(induction phase).
    • Followed by Fluconazole for maintenance therapy.

Key Takeaway

Brain imaging shows abnormalities in 80% of Cryptococcal meningitis case.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed to have scrub typhus developed high grade fever and cough. What is the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
Choice C: IV Doxycycline plus Azithromycin

  • Scrub typhus is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi and is transmitted by mite (chigger) bites.
  • The patient has high-grade fever and cough, suggesting scrub typhus pneumonia, a known complication.
  • Treatment for severe scrub typhus with pulmonary involvement:
    • IV Doxycycline (first-line drug for scrub typhus).
    • IV Azithromycin (added for severe cases, especially in doxycycline-resistant regions or for pneumonia and CNS involvement).
    • Azithromycin is also preferred in pregnant women and children <8 years(since doxycycline can cause tooth discoloration).

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: IV Doxycycline

  • Doxycycline alone is usually sufficient for mild to moderate scrub typhus.
  • However, for severe cases (with pneumonia, ARDS, or CNS involvement), Azithromycin is added for better efficacy.

Choice B: IV Doxycycline plus Ceftriaxone

  • Ceftriaxone is not effective against scrub typhus, as Orientia tsutsugamushilacks a typical bacterial cell wall.
  • This combination is not standard for treating scrub typhus pneumonia.

Choice D: IV Ceftriaxone plus Azithromycin

  • Ceftriaxone has no role in scrub typhus.
  • Azithromycin alone can be used if doxycycline is contraindicated, but ceftriaxone does not provide additional benefit.

Key Takeaway

For severe scrub typhus with pneumonia, IV Doxycycline + IV Azithromycin is the preferred treatment.

questions.text: All of the following organisms are transmitted by the vector shown in the image except? Image of a tick
questions.solution:
Choice B: Orientia tsutsugamushi (Scrub Typhus - NOT Tick-Borne)

  • The image shows a tick, which transmits tick-borne diseases.
  • However, Orientia tsutsugamushi (Scrub Typhus) is NOT transmitted by ticks, but by mites (chiggers - Leptotrombidium species).
  • Scrub typhus is transmitted through the bite of infected larval mites, commonly found in grassy and forested areas (scrublands).

Incorrect Choices Explanation (Tick-borne diseases)

Choice A: Babesia (Babesiosis)

  • Babesiais a tick-borne protozoan that infects red blood cells.
  • Transmitted by Ixodes ticks(same vector as Lyme disease).
  • Causes hemolytic anemia, fever, and hepatosplenomegaly.

Choice C: Ehrlichia (Ehrlichiosis)

  • Ehrlichia chaffeensiscauses human monocytic ehrlichiosis (HME).
  • Transmitted by Amblyomma (Lone Star tick).
  • Symptoms: Fever, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes.

Choice D: CCHF (Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic Fever)

  • Caused by Nairovirus (Bunyaviridae).
  • Transmitted by Hyalomma ticks.
  • Causes high fever, hemorrhagic manifestations, and multi-organ failure.

Key Takeaway

The only organism in the list that is NOT tick-borne is Orientia tsutsugamushi (Scrub Typhus), which is transmitted by mite larvae (chiggers), not ticks.

questions.text: WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING RECEPTORS HELPS THE HIV-1 GENOME TO ENTER INSIDE THE HOST CELL?
questions.solution:
• HIV-1 entry into host cells requires interaction between:
    • gp120 (on the viral envelope) and CD4 receptor (on host cells).
    • After CD4 binding, gp120 interacts with a co-receptor (CCR5 or CXCR4), facilitating viral entry.
    • CCR5 is the primary co-receptor used in the early stages of infection, allowing HIV to enter macrophages and T cells.
    • Individuals with a CCR5-Δ32 mutation have resistance to HIV infection.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: gp120

  • gp120 is an HIV surface glycoprotein that binds to CD4 and co-receptors (CCR5 or CXCR4).
  • It mediates attachment but does not directly help the viral genome enter the host cell.

Choice B: gp41

  • gp41 is a transmembrane protein responsible for fusion between the viral and host cell membranes.
  • It helps HIV inject its genome into the host cell but does not act as a receptor.

Choice C: CXCR4

  • CXCR4 is a co-receptor used in later stages of HIV infection, mainly in T-tropic (X4) strains.
  • However, CCR5 is used predominantly in initial infection, making it the better answer.

Key Takeaway

CCR5 is the primary receptor that helps HIV-1 enter host cells during early infection.
